comments:
It fails to complete installation and tells me to look at
workspace/.metadata/.log.  That contains:

!SESSION 
----------------------------------------------------------------------
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Sep 19, 2002 14:24:21.847
!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
!STACK
java.lang.VerifyError: (class: 
org/eclipse/core/internal/plugins/PluginParser, method: initializeParser 
signature: ()V) Incompatible object argument for function call
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.plugins.RegistryLoader.processManifestFile(RegistryLoader.java:89)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.plugins.RegistryLoader.processPluginPathFile(RegistryLoader.java:136)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.plugins.RegistryLoader.processPluginPathEntry(RegistryLoader.java:127)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.plugins.RegistryLoader.processManifestFiles(RegistryLoader.java:104)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.plugins.RegistryLoader.parseRegistry(RegistryLoader.java:63)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.plugins.RegistryLoader.parseRegistry(RegistryLoader.java:71)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.parsePlugins(InternalPlatform.java:742)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.loadRegistry(InternalPlatform.java:686)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.loaderStartup(InternalPlatform.java:562)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at 
sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at 
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.startup(InternalBootLoader.java:909)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run(InternalBootLoader.java:768)
	at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:462)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at 
sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at 
sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:247)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:703)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:539)

This is SuSE Linux 8.0, release 2.4.18-4GB.

Java is:

java version "1.4.0"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.0-b92)
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.0-b92, mixed mode)

I had previously gone quite some distance with the
previous release of Eclipse on this box, but it claimed
that the team.cvs_ui plugin was deactivated, and
thus would not do cvs.  I could not figure out how to make
that plugin active again.  I would call that a bug, but
it is entirely consistent with the maze-o-twisty passages
UI design that Eclipse has, and given my experience in that
maze I decided that a clean install would be more expedient
than spending further time looking for a fix.

I suspect that there is something somehow changed/wrong with
my configuration (what deactivated cvs, after all, and why?)
but I am unable to tell what, and apparently eclipse can't
tell any better than I can.
The stack trace suggests that the class files in your install are somehow
invalid or corrupt.  What build of Eclipse were you trying to install? Did you
try downloading the build more than once with the same results?
I do not know how to determine the build if I cannot run
Eclipse.  It was identified as "2.0.1" when I downloaded
it, whatever is the non-exciting release with that identity.

I set aside the "workspace" subdirectory of 2.0 and
tried running it, and it failed in exactly the same way.

I tried changing the VM to 1.4.1, and it failed in
exactly the same way.

I checked my home directory for files (dot or otherwise)
containing "eclipse", saw none.

I checked my environment for any occurrence of the string
"eclipse", saw none.

I do suspect some subtle dependence on my environment or
installation, but I cannot tell what it might be.  I do not
think that the bits in the downloaded file are themselves
corrupted; that seems unlikely, given how rarely that usually
happens, and given how the failure is now the same for 2.0 as
it is for 2.0.1
In addition, I re-downloaded it, cmp'd to the original,
they were identical, deleted both the 2.0 and 2.0.1 versions
that I had previously unpacked, unpacked the new one, ran it
and saw the same error.

Again, I think there is a subtle dependence on my environment.
I tried running again with PATH and CLASSPATH set to minimal values,
but it continued to fail in the same way.

I tried "eclipse --help" to see if I can learn about logging or
debugging options, but instead it continued to fail in the same
way.

I tried running it (from the same directory) from another machine
on the same LAN, but it continued to fail in the same way.

Any clues about what eclipse might be depending on would be helpful.
I have exhausted my list of usual suspects, and I realize that this
is likely to be a difficult-to-reproduce bug.  It could be pilot
error, but this pilot has been using eclipse for months on a Windows
box, and used it successfully for weeks on this Linux box.  Something
changed.
After disassembling the bytecodes (I imagine there is source
somewhere, but I'm handy with bytecodes, and that way I don't
need to worry about whether I am reading the same thing I am
running) I noticed a reference in the relevant method to
org.xml.sax.InputSource.  

Turns out that there is a version of xerces placed in the
"jre/lib/endorsed" (new with 1.4.*, I think) directory of
our java install, and apparently it is Not Compatible with
Eclipse 2.0 or 2.0.1.  By running against an unenhanced
version of the 1.4.0 JRE, I got Eclipse to work just fine.

The offending jar file was one of:

/usr/local/Avalon-4.1.2/avalon-framework-4.1.2.jar
/usr/local/OpenORB-1.2.1/dist/openorb-1.2.1.jar
/usr/local/xalan-j_2_3_1/bin/xalan.jar
/usr/local/xerces-1_4_4/xerces.jar

Write Once, Run ....?

I think someone needs to make a note of this.

traces.message: (class:  org/eclipse/core/internal/plugins/PluginParser, method: initializeParser  signature: ()V) Incompatible object argument for function call
